title: Argentina
description:
Argentina recognizes that the adequate availability of internationally controlled substances for medical and scientific purposes is an essential element of the right to health, and it is essential to strike a balance between the availability of the aforementioned substances for these purposes and the need to avoid the diversion of them towards illicit purposes.

title: Australia
description:
We encourage countries to work on the availability and access of controlled substances for medical purposes.

Statement in context

Australia remains particularly concerned about the global inequality in access to controlled substances given that almost 80% of the world’s population lacks adequate access to pain relief

title: El Salvador
description:
It is very important, in keeping with UNGASS 2016, that substances remain available for scientific and medical purposes, which is why we’re proposing a resolution in this regard.

title: Jamaica
description:
Jamaica is also encouraged by the UNODC, WHO for work in access to controlled substances, particularly for hospice and palliative care. This presently remains woefully inadequate.

Statement in context

Continued delays will not improve access for patients to palliative care and other forms of illness, such as wasting syndrome, epilepsy. They deserve this alternative where other options have failed.

title: Kenya
description:
Control on abuse of pharmaceutical drugs through monitoring and surveillance has led to the recall and rescheduling of certain substances. Kenya is focussed on ensuring affordability and availability of controlled medicines while ensuring efficacy.

Statement in context

title: Nepal
description:
We are committed to further achieve adequate access and availability of controlled substances for medical and scientific purposes while preventing their diversion.

title: Russia
description:
Access to narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances for those who need them for medical purposes has been established in our country as a government priority. Budget legislation 2019-24 has provided a separate budget line to carry out measures necessary to ensure patients have necessary medical equipment and medicines, this includes pain relievers.

title: Singapore
description:
We are supportive of measures to ensure the availability and access of controlled substances for medical and scientific uses. However, we would like to reiterate our concerns that the ECDDA’s recommendations will lose the controls over cannabis, leading to a widening public access and cause serious public health and safety issues.

title: Switzerland
description:
Switzerland places health at the heart of its drug policy, which is why we find it intolerable to note the suffering lived through by millions of people not given assistance – even palliative care.

title: Turkey

Under the coordination of the Ministry of Health, tangible progress has been achieved in the provision of better public services in the treatment and rehabilitation fields as well as availability of the controlled substances.

title: United Kingdom
